column2: She is eight years old and learns everything by heart. Something may come of her for she has talent, but not if she goes on as she is doing now; she will never acquire velocity because she purposely makes her hand heavy.
column3: She is eight years old and learns everything by heart. Something may come of her for she has talent, but not if she goes on as she is doing now; she will never acquire velocity because she purposely makes her hand heavy.

column2: She will never learn the most necessary, most difficult and principal thing in music, that is time, because from childhood she has designedly cultivated the habit of ignoring the beat."

column2: If she does not get some thoughts and ideas (for now she has absolutely none), it will all be in vain, for God knows, I can not give her any.	If she does not get some thoughts and ideas (for now she has absolutely none), it will all be in vain, for God knows, I can not give her any.

column2: It is not her father's intention to make a great composer out of her.
column3: It is not her father's intention to make a great composer out of her.

column2: 'She shall,' he says, 'not write any operas, or arias, or symphonies, but only great sonatas for her instrument and mine!' I gave her her fourth lesson today, and so far as the rules of composition and her exercises are concerned I am pretty well satisfied with her.
column3: 'She shall,' he says, 'not write any operas, or arias, or symphonies, but only great sonatas for her instrument and mine!' I gave her her fourth lesson today, and so far as the rules of composition and her exercises are concerned I am pretty well satisfied with her.

column2: She wrote a very good bass to the first minuet which I set her, and has already begun to write in three parts.
column3: She wrote a very good bass to the first minuet which I set her, and has already begun to write in three parts.

column2: It goes, but she gets bored too quickly.
column3: It goes, but she gets bored too quickly.

column2: I can not help her; progress is impossible, she is too young even if she had talent.
column3: I can not help her; progress is impossible, she is too young even if she had talent.

column2: Unfortunately she has none; she must be taught artificially; she has no ideas, there are no results, I have tried in every sort of way.
column3: Unfortunately she has none; she must be taught artificially; she has no ideas, there are no results, I have tried in every sort of way.

column2: Among other things it occurred to me to write down a very simple minuet and to see if she could write a variation on it.
column3: Among other things it occurred to me to write down a very simple minuet and to see if she could write a variation on it.

column2: In vain.
column3: In vain.

column2: Well, thought I, it is because she does not know how to begin.
column3: Well, thought I, it is because she does not know how to begin.

column2: I then began a variation of the first measure and told her to continue it in the same manner; that went fairly well.
column3: I then began a variation of the first measure and told her to continue it in the same manner; that went fairly well.

column2: When she had made an end I asked her to begin something of her own,--only the first voice, a melody.
column3: When she had made an end I asked her to begin something of her own,--only the first voice, a melody.

column2: She thought a full quarter of an hour, and nothing came.
column3: She thought a full quarter of an hour, and nothing came.

column2: Thereupon I wrote four measures of a minuet and said to her: 'Now look what an ass I am; I have begun a minuet and can't finish even the first part; be good enough to finish it for me.' She thought it impossible.
column3: Thereupon I wrote four measures of a minuet and said to her: 'Now look what an ass I am; I have begun a minuet and can't finish even the first part; be good enough to finish it for me.' She thought it impossible.

column2: At length she produced a little something to my joy. Then I made her finish the minuet, i.e. only the first voice.
column3: At length she produced a little something to my joy. Then I made her finish the minuet, i e only the first voice.

column2: For her home work I have given her nothing to do except to alter my four measures and make something out of them, to invent another beginning, to keep to the harmony if she must, but to write a new melody.
column3: For her home work I have given her nothing to do except to alter my four measures and make something out of them, to invent another beginning, to keep to the harmony if she must, but to write a new melody.

column2: We shall see what comes of it tomorrow."

column2: The right hand is very good but the left utterly ruined.

column2: I can say that I often pity her when I see that she is obliged to labor till she gasps, not because she is unapt, but because she can't help it,--she is used to playing so, nobody ever taught her differently.
column3: I can say that I often pity her when I see that she is obliged to labor till she gasps, not because she is unapt, but because she can't help it,--she is used to playing so, nobody ever taught her differently.

column2: I said to her mother and her that if I were her regular teacher, I would lock up all her music, cover the keyboard with a handkerchief, and make her practice both hands at first slowly on nothing but passages, trills, mordents, etc., until the difficulty with the left hand was remedied; after that I am sure I could make a real clavier player out of her.
column3: I said to her mother and her that if I were her regular teacher, I would lock up all her music, cover the keyboard with a handkerchief, and make her practice both hands at first slowly on nothing but passages, trills, mordents, etc, until the difficulty with the left hand was remedied; after that I am sure I could make a real clavier player out of her.

column2: It is a pity; she has so much genius, reads respectably, has a great deal of natural fluency and plays with a great deal of feeling."
